title.narrative: F.a: Workers’ Rights and Combating Child Labour through Education

description.narrative: BWI is determined to work to eliminate child labour (CL) use in construction sector in South Asia. This widespread social problem is addressed at work place and community levels through developing social dialogue and collective agreements, awareness raisin g, up keeping six ex-CL schools, strengthening unions and enhancing terms and conditions at work places.The use of CL is still a massive social problem, which contribute to impoverishment. Children have a fundamental right to be children, to play, and the working belongs entirely to adults. On its worst, widespread use of child labor, prevent enhancement of principles of decent work.The access to schooling is a significant threshold to child laborers and their families. Health education and the work in Self Help Groups (SHG) offer benefits, which are often unique to poor families. In order to unions being able to continue offering these type of services to their members beyond the project cycle, it is crucial to continuously built unions’ capacities and re sources. Immediate results will be the up keeping of the six ex-child labor schools, which intake 540 pupils. In addition, 1 000 pupils will be transferred to Government schools. Around 120 pupils will receive vocational training. Unions aim to achieve ove r 40 000 new members. Fifteen work place committees and twenty SHGs are established. The union education will enhance the awareness on workplace safety and disaster management. The increased awareness enhances the elimination of child labor use, the social protection and collective agreements at work place and national levels.Main beneficiaries are ex-child laborers, who would have no other chance for education. The biggest beneficiary group are the informal construction workers. Women and young workers wil l be better able to participate in union activities and further issues important for them.BWI and BWI Nepal Affiliates Committee (BWI NAC) coordinate the project and the implementation at local level will be conducted by BWI affiliates in Nepal and India.
